message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pulmonary hypertension. Right-heart catheterization is considered the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary hypertension as it directly measures pulmonary artery pressure. The other options (CT angiography, Doppler echocardiography, high-resolution CT of the lung) may provide additional information but are not definitive for diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest pulmonary hypertension. Doppler echocardiography can confirm the diagnosis, but the gold standard is right-heart catheterization, which can measure the pressure inside the pulmonary arteries. CT angiography and high-resolution CT of the lung may show pulmonary hypertension but cannot confirm it definitively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pulmonary hypertension. Right-heart catheterization is the diagnostic test of choice for pulmonary hypertension. CT angiography and Doppler echocardiography can also be used to diagnose pulmonary hypertension, but they are not as accurate as right-heart catheterization. High-resolution CT of the lung is more useful for diagnosing interstitial lung disease rather than pulmonary hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure, which can be confirmed with right-heart catheterization. CT angiography may show central pulmonary arteries, but it does not confirm the diagnosis. Doppler echocardiography may show right ventricular enlargement and pulmonary hypertension, but it does not provide definitive confirmation. High-resolution CT of the lung may show underlying lung disease, but it does not confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure.
